qas.question: Who was the supplier of copper and cobalt to China?

answers.text: they dig the ore by hand, carry sacks of ores on their backs

qas.question: What percent of materials go to China?
What is the cobalt used for?

answers.text: lithium-ion batteries powering electric cars and mobile devices worldwide

context: In 2008, Bloomberg claimed child labour in copper and cobalt mines that supplied Chinese companies in <a0_0>Congo<a0_0/>. The children are creuseurs, that is <a1_0>they dig the ore by hand, carry sacks of ores on their backs<a1_0/>, and these are then purchased by these companies. Over 60 of Katanga's 75 processing plants are owned by Chinese companies and <a2_0>90 percent<a2_0/> of the region's minerals go to China. An African NGO report claimed 80,000 child labourers under the age of 15, or about 40% of all miners, were supplying ore to Chinese companies in this African region. Amnesty International alleged in 2016 that some cobalt sold by Congo Dongfang Mining was produced by child labor, and that it was being used in <a3_0>lithium-ion batteries powering electric cars and mobile devices worldwide<a3_0/>.
